text: Alexander Crescenzi () was a seventeenth-century mathematician, translator, and scholar living in Rome. He was a Jewish convert to Christianity. Crescenzi became celebrated on account of his report, which he edited with mathematical notes, on the 1660 eruption of Mount Vesuvius. He also translated the Tradado de Chocolate ("Treatise on Chocolate") of Antonio Colmener de Ledesma from Spanish into Italian, published in Rome in 1667 with notes by Alexander Vitrioli. ==References== * Category:17th-century Italian mathematicians Category:17th-century Italian writers Category:17th-century male writers Category:Converts to Christianity from Judaism Category:Italian people of Jewish descent Category:People of Italian-Jewish descent Category:Writers from Rome
